<strong>Melodic Pattern</strong>
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\hline
\\[-1em]
\text{ } \quad \text{ } \quad \text{ } \quad \text{ }\quad \text{◎}\quad \text{ }\quad \text{ } \\
\hline
\\[-1em]
\text{ } \quad \text{○} \quad \text{ } \quad \text{○}\quad \text{ }\quad \text{○}\quad \text{ } \\
\hline
\\[-1em]
\text{●} \quad \text{ } \quad \text{●} \quad \text{ }\quad \text{ }\quad \text{ }\quad \text{●} \\
\hline
\end{array}
$$
<br>
<br>
<strong>(Non-) Prominence Types</strong><br>
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text{●: L, one-beat long, low pitch}\\
\text{○: H, one-beat long, high pitch}\\
\text{◎: H+, two-beat long, extra high}
\end{array}
$$
</div>

#A Well-known Nursery Rhyme in Kazakh
<br>
###If we find two prominence types in a nursery rhyme, could we be inspired, that a language is allowed to exhibit **more than one type of prominence**.

<br>
<br>

###Some prior assumptions in this study need phonetic examinations:

1. Word-level prominence is **stress**, and it is realised with a **longer vowel** and a **higher pitch**

2. Phrase-level prominence is **pitch accent**, and it is realised with a **higher pitch**

---
#Grammar Assumed - Sequential Assignment
.pull-left[
- An analysis of *Optimality Theory* is proposed <br> <br>
- Kazakh is assumed to exhibit **four**-level prominence (word, phrasal, sentential and intonational) <br> <br>
- The input to **word-level stress assignment** is unparsed syllables <br> <br>
- The input to the next stage is the output of the previous stage <br> <br>
- At each level, there is a **default** prominence position (prominent at previous stage, etc.) <br> <br>
- Deviating from the default position will lead to **contrastive focus** at that level
]
.pull-right[
<div style="text-align: center;">
<img src="images/frame.png" height="500ptx">
</div>
]

#Word-level Stress is NOT limited to the Stem Only
$$
\boldsymbol{H_0}: \text{Only word stem is qualified to be a phonological word}.
$$
$$
\boldsymbol{H_1}: \text{Both word stem and suffixed word are qualified to be phonological words.}
$$

#Minimal Parsing vs. Maximal Parsing
.pull-left[
### Minimal Parsing
<span style="font-variant: small-caps;">AllFeetRight >> AllFeetLeft >> Parse-</span>σ
<br>
<br>
$$
\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\quad\rightarrow\quad\sigma\sigma(\sigma\sigma)
$$
$$
\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\quad\rightarrow\quad\sigma\sigma\sigma(\sigma\sigma)
$$
]
.pull-right[
### Maximal Parsing
<span style="font-variant: small-caps;">Parse-</span>σ<span style="font-variant: small-caps;"> >> AllFeetRight >> AllFeetLeft</span>
<br>
<br>
$$
\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\quad\rightarrow\quad(\sigma\sigma)(\sigma\sigma)
$$
$$
\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\sigma\quad\rightarrow\quad\sigma(\sigma\sigma)(\sigma\sigma)
$$
]
<br>
<br>
<br>
We argue for <strong>maximal parsing<strong>
